title: The Effects of Resistance Training Volume on Osteosarcopenic Obesity in Older Women

sections.abstract:
The aim of this study was to analyze the effects of resistance training (RT) performed with 1 or 3 sets per
exercise on osteosarcopenic obesity (OSO) syndrome parameters in older women. Sixty-two older
women (68.0 ± 4.3 years, 26.8 ± 4.4 kg/m
2) participated in a 12-week RT program. Participants were
randomly assigned into one of the three groups: two training groups that performed either 1 set (G1S,
n = 21) or 3 sets (G3S, n = 20) 3 times weekly, or a control group (CG, n = 21). Body composition was
assessed by dual X-ray absorptiometry, strength was evaluated by 1 repetition maximum testing. The
G3S presented significantly higher strength changes than G1S. The changes for percentage of body fat
were higher for G3S compared to G1S. There was no difference in skeletal muscle mass between G3S
and G1S, however both training groups displayed greater increases in this outcome compared to CG.
There was no effect for bone mineral density. The overall analysis indicated higher (P < 0.05) positive
changes for G3S than G1S (composed Z-score: G3S = 0.62 ± 0.40; G1S = 0.11 ± 0.48). The
sections.results:
suggest
that a 12-week RT period is effective to improve the risk factors of OSO, and that 3 sets induce higher
improvements than a single set.
ARTICLE HISTORY
Accepted 3 November 2017
KEYWORDS
Aging; strength training;
muscle mass; bone mineral
density; body fatIntroduction
Obesity, sarcopenia, and osteopenia/osteoporosis are fre-
quently observed during the aging process and evidence of
systemic interactions between adipose, skeletal muscle mass
(SMM) and bone tissues have been documented (Argilés,
López-Soriano, Almendro, Busquets, & López-Soriano,
2005;
Gimble, Zvonic, Floyd, Kassem, & Nuttall, 2006; Lee &
Karsenty, 2008; Rasouli & Kern, 2008; Rosen & Bouxsein,
2006). Research suggests that, particularly in postmenopausal
women, a concurrent appearance of obesity with low bone
and SMM and muscular strength results in a combined condi-
tion termed as osteosarcopenic obesity (OSO) (Ilich et al.,
2014;
Ormsbee et al.,2014).
Obesity alone is related to type II diabetes, heart disease,
sleep apnea, osteoarthritis, certain cancers, dyslipidemia, high
blood pressure, reproductive abnormalities, liver/gallbladder
disease, and stroke (Donnelly et al.,
2009). Sarcopenia, char-
acterized by progressive and generalized loss of SMM and
strength (Cruz-Jentoft et al.,
2010), may lead to disability,
and disability may further exacerbate sarcopenia (Janssen,
Baumgartner, Ross, Rosenberg, & Roubenoff,
2004) and
increase mortality in the oldest frail elderly (Landi et al.,
2013). On its own, osteoporotic individuals are at an increased
risk of bone fracture, a major cause of morbidity and mortality,
leading to loss of independence (Burge et al.,
2007). Further to
each component’s individual implications, more adverse out-
comes may be expected from combined disorders as one
disorder may cause another. For instance, sarcopenic obese
patients have a higher risk of impaired function falls (Rolland
et al.,
2009), disability (Baumgartner et al.,2004), diminished
quality of life (Stenholm et al.,2008), and knee osteoarthritis
(Lee, Kim, & Kim,2012) compared to those with normal body
composition.
Considering that all three tissues (fat, bone, and SMM) are
involved in physical function, measurements of physical or
functional performance may be used in a clinical setting to
screen individuals at risk of OSO. Ilich, Inglis, Kelly, and McGee
(
2015) have recently observed the lowest scores for handgrip
strength, walking speed, and balance in OSO postmenopausal
women compared to women who were only osteopenic obese,
sarcopenic obese, or obese (with normal bone and SMM).
Although the study has been conducted with a postmenopau-
sal population, the results showed that women with OSO are at
a higher risk for fractures and frailty (Ilich et al.,
2015).
Resistance training (RT) is a type of exercise that has been
shown to promote increases in muscular strength and hypertro-
phy (American College of Sports Medicine,
2009). Considerable
evidence exists that RT alone reduces fat while improving lipid
metabolism thus promoting a positive impact on obesity
(Donnelly et al.,
2009). RT interventions are also effective to
CONTACT Paolo M. Cunha pcunha88@hotmail.com Metabolism, Nutrition, and Exercise Laboratory, Londrina State University, Raposo Tavares Street, 855,
apartment 501, Londrina, Paraná, 86010-580, Brazil
JOURNAL OF SPORTS SCIENCES, 2017
https://doi.org/10.1080/02640414.2017.1403413
© 2017 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group
Downloaded by [University of Florida] at 07:17 11 November 2017 

improve BMD (Chodzko-Zajko et al.,2009; Kelley, Kelley, & Tran,
2001;M a r q u e s ,M o t a ,&C a r v a l h o ,2012; Turner & Robling,2004).
The improvements associated with RT are dependent on
accurate manipulation of RT prescription variables, such as
intensity, volume, exercise order, rest intervals between sets
and exercises, and other training variables (American College
of Sports Medicine,
2009; Schoenfeld, 2010). Specific to train-
ing volume, this variable may be manipulated by the number
of sets performed per exercise (American College of Sports
Medicine,
2009; Schoenfeld, 2010). The number of sets per
exercise have a notable effect on physiological adaptations
due to RT performance, with several studies showing a dose-
response relationship between RT frequency and muscular
adaptations (Krieger,
2010; Schoenfeld, Ogborn, & Krieger,
2016; Wernbom, Augustsson, & Thomee,2007). However, the
precise RT number of sets has yet to be determined in indivi-
duals at risk for developing the OSO syndrome.
The aim of this study was to analyze the effect of RT per-
formed with 1 or 3 sets per exercise on OSO parameters in older
women. We hypothesized that RT would be effective to improve
the combined triad that underlies OSO syndrome parameters
and the higher volumes would elicit greater improvements.
sections.methods:
Participants
The recruitment of subjects was carried out through newspaper
and radio advertisings. Eighty-six Brazilian older women (≥
60 years old) volunteered to participate in this study. All partici-
pants completed a health history and met the following inclusion
criteria: 60 years old or more, physically independent, free from
c a r d i a co ro r t h o p e d i cd y s f u n c t i o n, not receiving hormonal repla-
cement therapy, and not performing any regular physical exercise
more than once a week in the six months preceding the beginning
of the investigation. After individual interviews, 18 volunteers
were excluded as potential candidates because they did not
meet inclusion criteria. The remaining 68 older women were
randomly divided into one of three groups: a group that per-
formed a program with 1 set per exercise (G1S, n = 23), a multi-
ple-set group that trained with 3 sets per exercise (G3S, n = 23), or
a control group (CG, n = 23) that did not perform any type of
physical exercise. A blinded rese a r c h e rw a sr e s p o n s i b l ef o rg e n -
erating random numbers (random.org) for group placement. A
total of 62 participants completed the experiment (G1S n = 21,
G3S n = 20, and CG n = 21) and were included in the analyses. The
reasons for withdrawal were reported as lack of time and personal
reasons. Adherence to the RT program was satisfactory, with all
participants reaching≥ 85% of the total sessions.
Figure 1presents
a schematic representation of the participant recruitment and
allocation adopted in this investigation.
Participants passed a diagnostic graded exercise stress test
with a 12-lead electrocardiogram, reviewed by a cardiologist,
and were released with no restrictions for participation in this
investigation. Written informed consent was obtained from all
participants after being provided with a detailed description of
investigation procedures. This investigation was conducted
according to the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by
the local University Ethics Committee.
Experimental design
This investigation was carried out over a period of 16 weeks,
with 12 weeks dedicated to the RT program and 4 weeks
allocated for measurements. Anthropometric, muscular
strength, and body composition evaluations were performed
in weeks 1– 2, and 15– 16 for baseline and post-intervention
scores. A supervised progressive RT program was performed
between weeks 3– 14 by the training groups (G1S and G3S).
The CG did not perform any type of physical exercise during
Figure 1. Flowchart of the study.
2 P. M. CUNHA ET AL.
Downloaded by [University of Florida] at 07:17 11 November 2017 

this period. The 1RM measurements were obtained during the
morning hours (from 8:00 to 11:00 am). The body composition
measurement was conducted during the afternoon (from
13:00 to 18:00 pm). The schedule of participants’ evaluations
was similar at pre- and post-training, thereby helping to
ensure consistency and thus internal validity. The post-training
measurements were performed at least 72 h after the final RT
session to avoid the acute effect of the last RT session.
Muscular strength
Maximal dynamic strength was evaluated using the 1 repetition
maximum (RM) test assessed in the chest press, knee extension
and preacher curl exercises, performed in this exact order.
Testing for each exercise was preceded by a warm-up set (6–
10 repetitions), with approximately 50% of the estimated load
used in the first attempt of the 1RM. This warm-up was also
used to familiarize the subjects with the testing equipment and
lifting technique. The testing procedure was initiated 2 min
after the warm-up. The subjects were instructed to try to
accomplish two repetitions with the imposed load and were
given three attempts in both exercises. The rest period was 3–
5 min between each attempt, and 5 min between exercises. The
1RM was recorded as the final load lifted in which the subject
was able to complete only one single maximal execution
(Amarante Do Nascimento et al.,
2013). Execution technique
for each exercise was standardized and continuously monitored
to ensure reliability. All 1RM testing sessions were supervised by
2 experienced researchers for greater safety and integrity of the
subjects. The highest load achieved in the 3 sessions was used
for analysis in each exercise. The muscular strength was deter-
mined by the sum of the 3 exercises, that is, the load lifted in
chest press plus the load lifted in the knee extension plus the
load lifted in the preacher curl.
Body composition
Whole-body dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) (Lunar
Prodigy, model NRL 41,990, GE Lunar, Madison, WI) was used
to assess body fat, appendicular lean soft tissue, and bone
mineral density (BMD). Prior to scanning, participants were
instructed to remove all objects containing metal. Scans
were performed with the subjects lying in the supine position
along the table’s longitudinal centerline axis. Feet were taped
together at the toes to immobilize the legs while the hands
were maintained in a pronated position within the scanning
region. Both calibration and analyses were carried out by a
skilled laboratory technician. Equipment calibration followed
the manufacturer’s recommendations. The software generated
standard lines that set apart the limbs from the trunk and
head. These lines were adjusted by the same technician using
specific anatomical points determined by the manufacturer.
Analyses during the intervention were performed by the same
technician throughout the investigation, who was blinded to
group identity. The SMM was estimated from the quantifica-
tion of lean tissue and appendicular soft, by using the pre-
dictive equation proposed by Kim et al. (Kim, Wang,
Heymsfield, Baumgartner, & Gallagher,
2002).
Osteosarcopenic obesity
The parameters of osteosarcopenic obesity syndrome risk fac-
tors were: muscular strength, SMM, percentage of body fat, and
BMD. A Z-score of the percentage changes (from pre- to post-
training) of the raw data for each parameter was calculated.
Thus, a composite Z-score, derived from the average of the
components was calculated as following formula: (muscular
strength Z-core) + (SMM Z-score) + (−1 x body fat Z-score) +
(BMD Z-score)/4.
Resistance training program
The RT training program was based on recommendations for
RT in an older population (American College of Sports
Medicine,
2009). Individually, each participant was personally
supervised by physical education professionals. The sessions
were performed 3 times per week on Mondays, Wednesdays,
and Fridays. The RT program was performed in the following
order: chest press, horizontal leg press, seated row, knee
extension, preacher curl (free weights), leg curl, triceps push-
down, and seated calf raise. Participants of the G1S performed
1 set of 10– 15 repetitions maximum for each exercise, while
the G3S performed 3 sets of 10– 15 repetitions maximum for
each exercise (1 a 2 min rest interval between sets). Both
groups performed sets until repetition failure defined as the
inability to perform the exercise with proper form. Participants
were instructed to inhale during the eccentric phase and
exhale during the concentric phase while maintaining a con-
stant velocity of movement at a ratio of approximately 1:2
seconds (concentric and eccentric phases, respectively). The
rest interval between each exercise was 2– 3 min. The training
load was consistent with the prescribed number of repetitions
for each exercise. The duration of training for the G1S lasted
30 min while that for G3S was 50 min. Progression was
planned when the upper limits of the repetitions-zone were
completed for two consecutive training sessions, then weight
was increased 2– 5% for the upper limb exercises and 5– 10%
for the lower limb exercises to the next session (American
College of Sports Medicine,
2009).
Statistical analyses
One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and chi-square tests
were used to compare the control and intervention groups
regarding the general characteristics and clinical conditions
(categorical variables), respectively. To examine differences
among groups on changes in muscular strength, percentage
of body fat, SMM, and BMD, a two-way analysis of covariance
(ANCOVA) for repeated measures was performed with the
baseline scores used as a covariate to eliminate any possible
influence of initial score variances on training outcomes (Senn,
2013; Van Breukelen,2006; Vickers & Altman,2001). When the
F-ratio was significant, the 95% confidence interval was used
to determine whether a significant difference existed between
adjusted ANCOVA mean at pre- and post-training as well as
the post-training differences among groups, and the
Bonferroni’s post hoc test was employed to identify the
mean differences between pre- and post-training raw data.
JOURNAL OF SPORTS SCIENCES
3
Downloaded by [University of Florida] at 07:17 11 November 2017 

To verify the differences among groups on the isolated and
composite Z-scores, a one-way ANOVA was applied; when the
F-ratio was significant, a Bonferroni ’s post hoc test was
employed to identify the mean differences. Significance was
accepted at P < 0.05. Effect size (ES) was calculated as post-
training mean minus pre-training mean divided by the pooled
standard deviation (Cohen,
1992). The data were analyzed
using SPSS software, version 21.0 (SPSS inc., Chicago, IL, USA).
Results
The general characteristics and clinical conditions of the parti-
cipants according to groups are described in
Table 1. There
were no significant differences (P > 0.05) among groups at
baseline for any variable analyzed.Table 2 presents the mus-
cular strength and body composition components values at
pre and post-training. Both training groups increased their
scores from pre- to post-training for SMM and strength,
while CG decreased its score for strength. G3S presented a
reduction in relative body fat after the intervention period.
The covariate means as well as the adjusted post-training
scores of the OSO syndrome components according to groups
are presented in
Figure 2. A volume effect was observed to
muscular strength and percentage of body fat (Panels A and C,
respectively), in which the G3S presented significantly higher
muscular strength scores than G1S and CG, and the G1S score
was significantly higher compared to CG; whereas scores for
percentage of body fat for G3S were lower compared to G1S
and CG, and the G1S was lower than CG. For SMM (Panel B)
there was no difference between G3S and G1S, however both
training groups achieved higher scores when compared to CG.
For BMD (Panel D), there were no differences among groups
and between pre- and post-training scores.
The Z-scores of the percentage changes from pre- to post-
training for each component are presented in
Table 3. The
composite Z-score of the percentage changes from pre- to
post-training of the OSO syndrome parameters according to
group are displayed in
Figure 3. A significant (P < 0.05) volume
effect was observed, whereby the G3S presented higher posi-
tive variation than others groups, and G1S presented higher
value in comparison to CG (composed Z-score:
G3S = 0.62 ± 0.40; G1S = 0.11 ± 0.48; CG =−0.70 ± 0.42).
sections.discussion:
The main and novel finding of the present investigation was
that 12 weeks of RT induced improvements on OSO compo-
nents in older women, and this adaptation is influenced by RT
volume. We had hypothesized that the training protocol con-
sisting of 3 sets per exercise would provide greater positive
improvements in the risk factors of OSO syndrome; this
hypothesis was confirmed.
The overall changes induced by RT in OSO syndrome para-
meters were expressed by percentage changes in a composite
Z-score. This approach may be an important tool to estimate
the effect of training, because it considers the overall response
of a RT program, allowing the ability to draw inferences of the
intervention as a whole as opposed to isolated outcomes. In
this investigation, we found that 3 sets per exercise resulted in
higher changes in the composite Z-score, indicating that of
the whole sample, the participants who performed the RT with
a higher volume achieved greater positive improvements.
However, it should be noted that each G1S session took
~15 min to complete, whereas G3S sessions lasted ~45 –
50 min. Thus, G1S may be an attractive option if time effi-
ciency of training is a concern, provided the individual is will-
ing to sacrifice some added improvements in muscular
strength, body fat and muscle hypertrophy. In this regard, RT
prescription should take into account an individual’s lifestyle
and preferences when determining the volume of training, as
this may improve motivation and adherence to exercise.

To our knowledge this is the first randomized clinical trial
addressing the effects of a RT volume on parameters of OSO
syndrome. Because of the novelty of our analysis, no direct
comparisons can be made with the current literature.
However, some studies have showed the benefits of a regi-
mented RT program on sarcopenic obesity (Balachandran,
Krawczyk, Potiaumpai, & Signorile,
2014; Gadelha, Paiva,
Gauche, De Oliveira, & Lima,2016; Stoever, Heber, Eichberg,
& Brixius, 2016).
Nevertheless, several studies have analyzed each component
individually in the target population. Regarding muscular
strength, the higher increases observed in G3S vs. G1S are in
agreement with previous work from our laboratory in another
cohort of older women (Ribeiro et al.,
2015). A meta-analysis
indicates that multiple (2– 3 sets) sets are superior than single
set to elicit muscular strength (Krieger,2010). However, some
studies that directly compared the effects of performing 1 set
versus 3 sets on strength outcomes in older women did not
observe differences between protocols in strength gains
(Cannon & Marino,
2010;R a d a e l l ie ta l . ,2013). These conflicting
results may be related to methodological approaches. For
example, Cannon and Marino (
2010) compared 1 versus 3 sets
of 10 repetitions with 75% of 1RM in a sample of older (60–
78 years) and young (20– 30 years) women 3 times a week for

Downloaded by [University of Florida] at 07:17 11 November 2017 

10 weeks with participants performing 2 exercises per session
(bilateral leg extension and bilateral leg curl). The results
showed that both groups achieved similar gains on maximal
knee extension strength independent of age. Considering that
participants in Cannon and Marino’s(
2010) study performed
only one exercise for the knee extensor muscles (bilateral knee
extension) while the participants in our experiment performed
2 exercises for the knee extensors (horizontal leg press and
knee extension machine), and that some studies indicate a
greater volume is necessary to achieve optimal improvements
in the lower versus upper limbs (Bottaro, Veloso, Wagner, &
Gentil,
2011; Paulsen, Myklestad, & Raastad,2003), it can be
hypothesized that the design of Cannon and Marino (2010)m a y
not have provided sufficient volume to induce differences in
strength gains between groups. Radaelli et al. (
2013) compared
1 set versus 3 sets in older women (60– 74 years) who per-
formed a 13-week RT program consisting of 10 exercises (bilat-
eral knee extension, lat pull-down, bilateral leg press, elbow
flexion, bilateral leg curl, bench press, triceps extension, hip
abduction and adduction and abdominal crunch) 3 times a
week with a load of 20RM, and did not observe differences in
knee extension and preacher curl strength gains between con-
ditions. It is noteworthy that the participants in Radaelli’se ta l .
(
2013) study performed the RT with a load of 20RM, thus using
lower intensities of load in comparison to ours. Because studies
indicate that there is a dose-response relationship between
magnitude of load and muscular strength increase in older
individuals (Borde, Hortobágyi, & Granacher,
2015; Csapo &
Alegre, 2015; Fatouros et al., 2005;R a y m o n d ,B r a m l e y -
Tzerefos, Jeffs, Winter, & Holland, 2013;S t e i b ,S c h o e n e ,&
Pfeifer, 2010), it is possible that the stimulus in the study by
Radaelli et al. (2013) may not have been adequate to elicit
maximal strength development. Moreover, this investigation
(Radaelli et al.,
2013) employed a twice a week training proto-
col, which thus resulted in an overall lower volume than ours. A
follow-up study on the topic (Radaelli et al.,
2014) investigated
the effects of 1 and 3 sets per exercise on knee extension and
arm flexor strength in older women (60– 74 years) with a routine
using the same exercises performed in their previous experi-
mental trial (Radaelli et al.,
2013). The 20-week RT program was
performed 2 times a week with progressive overload, in which
during the first 6 weeks participants trained with 15– 20 RM, in
weeks 7– 10 the load was 12-15RM, in weeks 11– 13 the load
was 10– 12 RM, in weeks 14– 17 load was 8-10RM, and during
the last 3 weeks the intensity was 6-8RM. The results indicated
that after 6 and 13 weeks of RT the increases in 1RM knee
extension was similar between 1 and 3 sets, however they
found a significant advantage of multi-set training on 1RM
knee extension only at the 20-week time point, corresponding
to the period that participants trained with higher loads. It is
not clear whether this result was influenced by the increased
loads over time, the longer time practice, or perhaps a combi-
nation of both factors.
A volume effect was also seen in changes in percent body
fat. Some studies indicate that RT sessions with 3 sets achieve
greater energy expenditure when compared to 1 set (Haddock
& Wilkin,
2006; Heden, Lox, Rose, Reid, & Kirk,2011; Mookerjee,
Welikonich, & Ratamess, 2016), without differences in post-
exercise energy expenditure. It therefore would be reasonable
to expect that the individuals who perform RT with higher
volumes would achieve greater fat loss. This hypothesis was
confirmed in our experiment. However, a previous study from
our laboratory comparing 1 versus 3 sets per exercises in
another cohort of older women (Ribeiro et al.,
2015) failed to
observe such differences between protocols. Recently, Nunes
et al. (
2016) investigated the effects of a 16-weeks RT program
(8 exercises, 3 times a week, 70% of 1RM) on body fat in 32
post-menopausal women who were separated into 3 groups: a
group that performed 3 sets per exercise, a group that per-
formed 6 sets per exercise, and a control group. Results indi-
cated no differences between the training groups for fat loss
(estimated by skinfold method). The reason for these discre-
pancies are not readily apparent, nevertheless we can spec-
ulate on some possibilities. Some individuals, especially
women, compensate for the exergy expended during exercise
by increasing their energy intake in a higher quantity than the
deficit induced by exercise (Donnelly & Smith,
2005; Emery,
Levine, & Jakicic, 2016; Finlayson, Bryant, Blundell, & King,
2009), and therefore blunting the positive effects of exercise
on fat loss. Whether compensation occurred cannot be deter-
mined as detailed food logs were not obtained in the studies.
We found similar increases in muscle mass between the G1S
and G3S conditions. These findings are inconsistent with recent
meta-analytic data showing a clear dose-response relationship
between RT volume and hypertrophic responses (Schoenfeld
et al.,
2016). It is possible that the use of DXA as proxy measure-
ment of muscle mass influenced results in these participants.
Although DXA is well-established as a valid modality for estimat-
ing body composition, it lacks the sensitivity to detect subtle
changes in muscle tissue over relatively short time frames com-
pared to more direct imaging measures such as magnetic reso-
nance image and computed tomography (Levine et al.,
2000).
This is particularly true in the elderly, where sarcopenic changes
result in a greater loss of skeletal muscle than surrounding
extracellular fluid and connective tissue (Maden-Wilkinson,
Degens, Jones, & McPhee,
2013; Proctor, O’Brien, Atkinson, &
Nair, 1999). It should be noted that the present study did show
greater absolute increases from the use of multiple versus single
sets (
Figure 2, Panel B), but these values did not rise to statistical
significance. Whether significant differences in hypertrophy
would have been detected by use of a more precise measure-
ment remains speculative.
With respect to BMD, RT is widely recommended as an
interventional strategy to improve bone health (Guadalupe-
Grau, Fuentes, Guerra, & Calbet,
2009; Kohrt et al.,2004). Such
recommendations are based on the body of evidence showing
a positive effect of the RT on bone health (Chodzko-Zajko
et al.,
2009; Kelley et al.,2001; Marques et al.,2012; Turner &
Robling, 2004). However, although 3SG and 1SG presented
higher post-training scores than CG (Figure 2, Panel D), results
did not reach statistical significance. Similar to the findings for
muscle mass, absolute increases in BMD favored G3S versus
G1S but no significant differences were noted. The lack of
positive benefits on this outcome may be related to the
short-term period of our intervention, as the time course for
bone remodeling occurs over a period of months. Future
research should seek to address potential differences in pro-
tocols over a longer timeframe.
6
P. M. CUNHA ET AL.
Downloaded by [University of Florida] at 07:17 11 November 2017 

The present study has some limitations. The results are
specific to physically independent older women and cannot
necessarily be extrapolated to other populations. Moreover,
we were not able to monitor physical activity levels and eating
habits outside of the study environment, which may have
confounded results. On the other hand, to our knowledge
the present study is the first randomized controlled trial to
investigate the effect of RT on a volume basis on OSO syn-
drome parameters in older women, thus representing an
important contribution to the current body of literature.
sections.conclusion:
We conclude that a 12-week RT program is effective to induce
improvement in OSO syndrome components, and that this
adaptation is volume-dependent with 3 sets inducing higher
improvements compared to a single set. This investigation
suggests a selective effect of RT on the OSO parameters with
impact on health and independent physical functioning in
older adult women.
Disclosure statement
No potential conflict of interest was reported by the authors.
